description: Perhaps from the term gypsy (“Roma”), due to a stereotype of the Roma as swindlers. Compare jew (“defraud”), from Jew, and welsh (“swindle by defaulting on a debt”), from Welsh.

entries.meaning: (derogatory, sometimes offensive) A cheat or swindle; a rip-off.
examples: Why do we have to buy this new edition of the textbook when there’s almost no difference between it and the previous one? What a gyp!

verbs.description: gyp (third-person singular simple present gyps, present participle gypping, simple past and past participle gypped)

entries.meaning: (derogatory, sometimes offensive) To cheat or swindle.
examples: The cab driver gypped me out of ten bucks by taking the longer route.
You better watch out; they'll try to gyp you if you don't know what you're doing.

description: Perhaps the same as Etymology 1. An earlier theory derived the term from Ancient Greek γύψ (gúps, “vulture”) (/ɡýps/; compare Greek γύπας (gýpas) /ˈʝi.pas/), "in reference to thievish habits of the servants" (and then derived Etymology 1 thence), but this does not explain the pronunciation.

entries.meaning: (Cambridge University, Durham University, historical) A domestic servant, generally male, who would attend upon (usually several) students, brushing their clothes, carrying parcels, waiting at parties and other tasks; generally equivalent to a scout in the historical sense at Oxford University or a skip at Trinity College, Dublin.
examples: Had he acted discourteously to his bedmaker or his gyp, he would have minded just as much … .

entries.meaning: (Cambridge University, Durham University) The room in which such college servants work.
(Cambridge University, Durham University) A small kitchen for use by college students.
